Who <FI>is<Fi> as the wise <FI>man<Fi>? and who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? a man's wisdom maketh his face to shine, and the boldness of his face shall be changed.<RF>the boldness: Heb. the strength<Rf>
I <FI>counsel thee<Fi> to keep the king's commandment, and <FI>that<Fi> in regard of the oath of God.
Be not hasty to go out of his sight: stand not in an evil thing; for he doeth whatsoever pleaseth him.
Where the word of a king <FI>is, there is<Fi> power: and who may say unto him, What doest thou?
Whoso keepeth the commandment shall feel no evil thing: and a wise man's heart discerneth both time and judgment.<RF>shall…: Heb. shall know<Rf><CM>
Because to every purpose there is time and judgment, therefore the misery of man <FI>is<Fi> great upon him.
For he knoweth not that which shall be: for who can tell him when it shall be?<RF>when…: or, how it shall be?<Rf>

<FI>There is<Fi> no man that hath power over the spirit to retain the spirit; neither <FI>hath he<Fi> power in the day of death: and <FI>there is<Fi> no discharge in <FI>that<Fi> war; neither shall wickedness deliver those that are given to it.<RF>discharge: or, casting off weapons<Rf><CM>
All this have I seen, and applied my heart unto every work that is done under the sun: <FI>there is<Fi> a time wherein one man ruleth over another to his own hurt.
And so I saw the wicked buried, who had come and gone from the place of the holy, and they were forgotten in the city where they had so done: this <FI>is<Fi> also vanity.
Because sentence against an evil work is not executed speedily, therefore the heart of the sons of men is fully set in them to do evil.
Though a sinner do evil an hundred times, and his <FI>days<Fi> be prolonged, yet surely I know that it shall be well with them that fear God, which fear before him:
But it shall not be well with the wicked, neither shall he prolong <FI>his<Fi> days, <FI>which are<Fi> as a shadow; because he feareth not before God.<CM>

There is a vanity which is done upon the earth; that there be just <FI>men<Fi>, unto whom it happeneth according to the work of the wicked; again, there be wicked <FI>men<Fi>, to whom it happeneth according to the work of the righteous: I said that this also <FI>is<Fi> vanity.

Then I commended mirth, because a man hath no better thing under the sun, than to eat, and to drink, and to be merry: for that shall abide with him of his labour the days of his life, which God giveth him under the sun.
When I applied mine heart to know wisdom, and to see the business that is done upon the earth: (for also <FI>there is that<Fi> neither day nor night seeth sleep with his eyes:)

Then I beheld all the work of God, that a man cannot find out the work that is done under the sun: because though a man labour to seek <FI>it<Fi> out, yet he shall not find <FI>it<Fi>; yea further; though a wise <FI>man<Fi> think to know <FI>it<Fi>, yet shall he not be able to find <FI>it<Fi>.<CM>
